title: How to Make a Can Planter or Candle Holder

steps.headline: Identify how you want to use the candle holder or planter.
steps.description: The use will dictate how large or small of a can you will need to use. For small votive candles, a little tuna can will do the trick. However for a substantial planter, a large can of crushed tomatoes might be more appropriate. Have supplies such as dirt, plants, candles, glass holders, etc. on hand before you begin the project.

steps.headline: Choose your cans.
Pick up a large bag of clothes pins.
steps.description: You will be encircling the can with the clothes pins, as they will become the outside of your decorative planter or candle holder. You’ll need several so don’t skimp on this purchase.

steps.headline: Line the sides of the can with the clothespins.
steps.description: You want to make sure the clothespins are placed directly next to each other (touching sides) so you don’t see the can underneath.

steps.headline: Place glass or plastic container inside the can.
steps.description: Of course beforehand make sure the container will fit. If you are using the holder for candles use a glass holder (plastic will melt).

steps.headline: Add candles or plants.
steps.description: This may mean that you either add dirt first and then plant seeds or you can transfer a plant directly from the temporary pot to your new holder.

text:
Pick up Supplies Identify how you want to use the candle holder or planter. The use will dictate how large or small of a can you will need to use. For small votive candles, a little tuna can will do the trick. However for a substantial planter, a large can of crushed tomatoes might be more appropriate. Have supplies such as dirt, plants, candles, glass holders, etc. on hand before you begin the project. Choose your cans. Ideally an empty tuna can works well, however small soup or other stouter cans will do the trick. Remove the food and then wash and rinse well. Make sure you use hot, soapy water when cleaning out the can and then dry thoroughly. You want the can to be completely dry so you avoid having it rust. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6f/Make-a-Can-Planter%2FCandle-Holder-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Can-Planter%2FCandle-Holder-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6f/Make-a-Can-Planter%2FCandle-Holder-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Can-Planter%2FCandle-Holder-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Remove the can label. Depending on the label you can either wash, peel or rub it away. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b0/Make-a-Can-Planter%2FCandle-Holder-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Can-Planter%2FCandle-Holder-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b0/Make-a-Can-Planter%2FCandle-Holder-Step-2Bullet2.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Can-Planter%2FCandle-Holder-Step-2Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Pick up a large bag of clothes pins. You will be encircling the can with the clothes pins, as they will become the outside of your decorative planter or candle holder. You’ll need several so don’t skimp on this purchase. Create the Planter/Candle Holder Line the sides of the can with the clothespins. You want to make sure the clothespins are placed directly next to each other (touching sides) so you don’t see the can underneath. Place glass or plastic container inside the can. Of course beforehand make sure the container will fit. If you are using the holder for candles use a glass holder (plastic will melt). Add candles or plants. This may mean that you either add dirt first and then plant seeds or you can transfer a plant directly from the temporary pot to your new holder. Finished.
